Posts.Content: tzane wrote: Hi all,  Since just before Halloween I've been feeling a weight on my chest which doesn't seem to go away and today it feels a little worse, almost like it is a little hard to breathe.  Slight cough too but not all the time.  I am getting really scared it could be lung mets.  I was dx Stage IIIA in 12/05.  I don't want to be a hypochondriac (plus with every ache and pain I think the worst) so should I just wait until I see my onc on 11/24 or do you think I should go see my family physician first?   Thanks so much for your help. Tabitha Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chest Pain tzane LuAnnH

Posts.Content: tzane wrote: I had 9 nodes removed from my right side a little over a year ago (4 had cancer). Over the past few days my right arm has started aching and it is not going away. The aching feeling is between my elbow and my shoulder. My fingers also ache a bit but my arm and fingers don't appear to be swollen. Any thoughts/advice? Not sure if it is worth calling the Dr. except the pain is getting worse. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Are these symptoms? tzane sherry7

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 11:55AM - edited Jul 2, 2010 11:57AM by tzane I had the same thing happen to me.  Here is what I did and here is how I got it covered at "in network" cost.  To back up a minute, the problem everywhere from what I've been told is the anesthesiologists normally don't belong to any network.  They figure they don't have too which the insurance companies don't like.  The first thing I did was talk to my HR rep who talked to the insurance company.  I said I used an in-network hospital, an in-network surgeon and was not in control of who would be the anesthesiologist.  I said, what was I to do as they were wheeling me in for my operation, ask if the anesthesiolgist was in-network and say don't cut if he was out of network.  My HR rep came back and said that the insurance company said I should have checked and it was my fault and responsibility.  So here is what I did.  I called the insurance company directly and asked them for a list of "in network" anesthesiologists at the hospital.  Said I may have to have surgery.  Guess what....there were NO in-network anesthesiologists.  So I went back to my HR rep and said how was I going to select an in-network anesthesiologist at the "in network" hospital if there weren't any.  The HR rep got back on the phone with the insurance company immediately and you know what, the insurance company folded and paid the in network rate.  They didn't have a leg to stand on.  Good luck!
